newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: EU ministers to grapple with treaty reforms.
newsitem.headline: EU ministers to grapple with treaty reforms.

text.p: European Union foreign ministers gather in this Dutch coastal resort later on Sunday in a bid to step up the pace of wide-ranging reform talks ahead of the mid-June Amsterdam summit.

The Dutch EU presidency called the extra ministerial session to inject fresh impetus into the inter-governmental conference (IGC) which began over a year ago, fearing that the IGC has been sidetracked by the high-profile run-up to monetary union and by attention given to trouble-spots such as Albania.
"This special conclave is aimed at keeping the reform process on track," a Dutch foreign ministry spokesman said.

Ministers, who got together two weeks ago in Rome to celebrate the bloc's 40th birthday, will focus on reviewing the Union's institutions which, many fear, could grind to a halt as the bloc expands eastwards over the next 10 years.
In an attempt to streamline policy-making, ministers will look at ways to trim the size of the executive European Commission and extend the scope of qualified majority voting.

On a more integrationist note, ministers will take another look at plans to incorporate the Western European Union (WEU), the bloc's fledgling defence club, into the EU, effectively creating a collective security policy and European army.
But the bloc's four neutral states, plus Britain, are unlikely to embrace a Franco-German-led plan for a phased move to a common defence policy.

With growing worker unrest across Europe and the biggest jobless figures in Germany since Hitler's rise to power, the EU also wants to signal to its 18 million unemployed that it cares about jobs by including an employment chapter in its social policy. This is fiercely opposed by Britain's ruling Conservatives, who fear the added costs for UK businesses.

The Dutch face a tight schedule to broker a revised Maastricht Treaty. If the IGC review is not completed by the June summit, accession talks with those wanting to join the bloc will be delayed and will risk becoming mired in crucial EMU decisions and French and German elections next year.
